citations.narrative:
On July 27, 2025, an adult female Ostrich was found deceased after becoming entrapped in a gap between the side and
back panels in a corner of its enclosure. According to facility staff, the animal’s head was entrapped between a temporary
side pipe corral panel and the permanent fencing of the enclosure. A smaller temporary enclosure was constructed inside
of the existing enclosure to facilitate exercise restriction and veterinary treatment due to an unrelated previous injury. The
pipe panel was approximately 5 feet tall allowing the animal to get its head over the top and lower its neck into the gap.
The gap was wide enough for the animal’s neck to fit, but not wide enough for the animal top pull its head back out of the
gap resulting in entrapment.
Enclosure design that allows birds to become entangled or entrapped can lead to stress, injury, or death. The licensee
must ensure that primary enclosures are constructed and maintained so that they protect the birds from injury.
Corrected prior to the inspection on September 23, 2025.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by October 26, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.153(a)(1)(ii)  Critical
   
Primary enclosures. 
On July 27, 2025, an adult female Ostrich was found deceased after becoming entrapped in a gap between the side and 
back panels in a corner of its enclosure. According to facility staff, the animal’s head was entrapped between a temporary 
side pipe corral panel and the permanent fencing of the enclosure. A smaller temporary enclosure was constructed inside 
of the existing enclosure to facilitate exercise restriction and veterinary treatment due to an unrelated previous injury. The 
pipe panel was approximately 5 feet tall allowing the animal to get its head over the top and lower its neck into the gap. 
The gap was wide enough for the animal’s neck to fit, but not wide enough for the animal top pull its head back out of the 
gap resulting in entrapment.  
 
Enclosure design that allows birds to become entangled or entrapped can lead to stress, injury, or death. The licensee 
must ensure that primary enclosures are constructed and maintained so that they protect the birds from injury. 
 
Corrected prior to the inspection on September 23, 2025. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by October 26, 2025, or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires. 
 
 n
